etymologies: Old English setlan ‘to seat, place’, from settle

definitions: resolve or reach an agreement about (an argument or problem)

examples.text: every effort was made to settle the dispute

shortDefinitions: resolve or reach agreement about

definitions: end (a legal dispute) by mutual agreement

examples.text: he sued for libel and then settled out of court
the matter was settled out of court

shortDefinitions: end legal dispute by mutual agreement

definitions: determine; decide on

examples.text: exactly what goes into the legislation has not been settled
they had not yet settled on a date for the wedding

shortDefinitions: reach decision about

definitions: complete the administration and distribution of a decedent's estate.
shortDefinitions: complete administration and distribution of decedent's estate

definitions: accept or agree to (something that one considers to be less than satisfactory)

examples.text: it was too cold for champagne so they settled for a cup of tea

shortDefinitions: accept or agree to

definitions: pay (a debt or account)

examples.text: his bill was settled by charge card
I settled up with your brother for my board and lodging

shortDefinitions: pay

definitions: give money or property to (someone) through a deed of settlement or a will

examples.text: he offered to settle $150 a year on her

shortDefinitions: give money or property to someone through deed of settlement

definitions: adopt a more steady or secure style of life, especially in a permanent job and home

examples.text: one day I will settle down and raise a family

shortDefinitions: adopt more steady or secure style of life

definitions: make one's permanent home somewhere

examples.text: in 1863 the family settled in London

shortDefinitions: make one's permanent home somewhere

definitions: move with a group of others to live in a new country or area

examples.text: European immigrants settled much of Australia

shortDefinitions: establish colony in

definitions: begin to feel comfortable or established in a new situation

examples.text: he had settled into his new job
she settled in happily with a foster family

shortDefinitions: begin to feel comfortable or established in new situation

definitions: turn one's attention to; apply oneself to

examples.text: Catherine settled down to her studies

shortDefinitions: turn one's attention to

definitions: become or make calmer or quieter

examples.text: after a few months the controversy settled down
try to settle your puppy down before going to bed

shortDefinitions: become or make calmer or quieter

definitions: silence (someone considered a nuisance) by some means

examples.text: he told me to hold my tongue or he would find a way to settle me

shortDefinitions: silence troublesome person by some means

definitions: sit or come to rest in a comfortable position

examples.text: he settled into an armchair

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of place

shortDefinitions: sit or come to rest in comfortable position

definitions: make (someone) comfortable in a particular place or position

examples.text: she allowed him to settle her in the taxi

notes.text: with object and adverbial of place

shortDefinitions: make someone comfortable in particular place or position

definitions: move or adjust (something) so that it rests securely

examples.text: she settled her bag on her shoulder

shortDefinitions: move or adjust something so that it rests securely

definitions: fall or come down onto a surface

examples.text: dust from the mill had settled on the roof

shortDefinitions: fall on to surface and remain there

definitions: (of suspended particles) sink slowly in a liquid to form sediment; (of a liquid) become clear or still through this process

examples.text: sediment settles near the bottom of the tank
he pours a glass and leaves it on the bar to settle

shortDefinitions: sink slowly in liquid to form sediment

definitions: (of an object or objects) gradually sink down under its or their own weight

examples.text: they listened to the soft ticking and creaking as the house settled

shortDefinitions: gradually sink down under its or their own weight

definitions: (of a ship or boat) sink gradually

examples.text: the craft was settling nose-down in the water

shortDefinitions: (of ship) begin to sink

etymologies: Old English setl ‘a place to sit’, of Germanic origin; related to German Sessel and Latin sella ‘seat’, also to sit

definitions: a wooden bench with a high back and arms, typically incorporating a box under the seat.
shortDefinitions: wooden bench with high back and arms
